Hi,
  copy constructors and assignment operators are implemented for the
th=
ermo routines, but not for the kinetics operator. That's why the
thermo par=
t of the copy worked, but not the kinetics part. 

I agree with Dave that t=
here's a definite cost and potential pitfalls to
developing and maintaining=
 them. There should be a definite reason for
their implementation.

I had i=
n the back of my mind, at one point, the case of solving
equilibrium proble=
ms with miscibility gaps, where the thermo phase would
need to be split int=
o two (e.g., III-V compound semiconductors which
obey the regular solution =
model) for some parameter regimes. I haven't
gotten there yet, though, in t=
erms of automagically splitting the phase
where appropriate. 

There's a di=
amondSurf_dupl test example that exercises the thermo
assignment operator.
=

Best wishes,
Harry Moffat

Dave,

Tha=
nks for the explanation. Is there any chance that the copy
constructor will=
 be implemented? I was hoping to be able to use them in
some of the standar=
d container classes, e.g. std::vector or std::list,
but I don't think this =
is possible without a functional copy
constructor. 

Also, it would be nice=
 to repeatedly read the input file from disk. Is
there a way to at least av=
oid this? I wasn't able to follow the
documentation well enough to know if =
this is possible.

Thanks,
Ray

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, Dave Goodwi=
n <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> The reason for this is that Cantera builds comp=
lete objects for use in

> C++ code from CTI or XML input files.  This main=
tains consistency with

> objects created from Python, Matlab, or Fortran.
=
> 
> The classes in the Cantera kernel (those in "Cantera/src/*" should 
> =
never be instantiated from copy constructors, but always from an input

> f=
ile or from a factory method designed for this purpose.  At the C++ 
> inte=
rface level (those files in Cantera/cxx/include/cantera, many of 
> the cla=
sses derive from multiple kernel classes, to provide (for 
> convenience on=
ly)  a single object that represents the thermodynamic 
> properties (equat=
ion of state) and the kinetics, at least for 
> homogeneous kinetics. I am =
in the process of changing the namespace 
> these classes live in to "Cante=
ra_CXX" to help avoid these confusions.
> 
> But still, I advise against us=
ing copy constructors or assignment 
> operators... These often cause more =
problems than they solve!!
> 
> Dave
> 
> The CVS repository will soon refl=
ect the namespace changes but does 
> not yet...
> 
> 
> 
> On Feb 13, 2008=
, at 5:32 AM, avmokhov wrote:
> 
> > Hi,
> > You can not use a copy constru=
ctor for an ideal gas mixture because 
> > the assignment operator is (stil=
l) not implemented. If you put try -

> > catch block you will catch a Cant=
era exception.
> >
> > Best regards, Anatoli
> >
> >
